div.head: Documentary Editing
div.p: Peter Shillingsburg argues that “an editorʼs fundamental orientation” to the question of authority, and “not the intrinsic merits of any textual problem,” tends to determine how editors assess textual problems and propose solutions (Shillingsburg, Scholarly Editing in the Computer Age, 54). [Discuss whether this is true of Juvenilia Press books. Aesthetic orientation there]

In fact, editorsʼ predilections aside, juvenilia do present an intrinsic case favoring documentary editing, since the authority tends not to be divided among multiple witnesses—and monolithic authority calls for historical, documentary treatment rather than the production of an eclectic text. In the case of the early Ruskin manuscripts, of the approximately 3? “works” (see Plan of the Edition) contained in Ruskinʼs written corpus between 1826 and 1842, 00 survive in solitary versions from that period. In 00 of those cases, the versions are represented by a single manuscript in draft or fair‐copy form; and in 00 of those cases, the versions survive in a single printed form. Another 00 of the 3? survive in two or more manuscript versions, typically one draft and one fair copy, but other combinations are extant. And 00 survive in some combination of draft and/or fair‐copy manuscript version plus a printed version produced within the time frame of the edition, 1826–42. Thus, a documentary approach seems intrinsically weighted by the fact that, in 00% of the extant cases, authority is not divided at all, being represented by a unique manuscript or printed witness; in 00% of cases, authority is divided between very few manuscript witnesses; and in only 00% of cases, authority is divided between witnesses that entail some degree of editorial intervention.

Alternatively, a case for an eclectic approach hinges on what happened when a given work was caught up in one or more of the three major editing projects involving the early manuscripts: the editing of Poems (1850) by John James Ruskin and W. H. Harrison; the editing of Poems (1891) by W. G. Collingwood, along with the editing (in a more modest sense of the term) and printing in the 1890s of various early prose works by George Allen; and the editing or reissue (the levels of intervention varied) of these and some additional early works by the editors of the Library Edition, E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn. I will argue that Ruskin himself was so little involved with these editorial projects that their interest is primarily sociological—that the editorsʼ orientation to this material at their differing historical moments is more interesting than Ruskinʼs involvement, who was disengaged by, and even contemptuous of the 1850 project, and who was supportive of, but unable to participate in the 1890s projects. Thus, the sociological interest of these editorial situations calls for a historical approach rather than one favoring an eclectic text.

In taking a documentary approach—what Mary‐Jo Kline defines as orienting a modern edition toward preserving the nuances of “inscribed artifacts whose unique physical characteristics and original nature give them special evidentiary value” (Kline, Guide to Documentary Editing, 2)—more is to be learned, I believe, about the early manuscripts both as imaginative works and as documents yielding evidence about the history of education, the early Victorian family, literary production in the marketplace of the annuals, scientific production in the marketplace of the natural history magazines, and the wealth of other historical, cultural, and biographical topics that early Ruskin corpus touches on. For the latter kinds of topics, the evidentiary value of the early manuscripts in their original form is self‐evident. As for these early works considered as imaginative creations, one must admit from the start that what interest they possess pales next to Ruskinʼs mature prose. Still, it is an essential to understanding Ruskin that he found an imaginative resource in revisiting his early writing and drawing—and doing so, it appears, by reexamining the early manuscripts and not, for example, Poems (1850) or the versions of his poems published in the annuals of the 1830s and 1840s. It is telling that, when Ruskin [1870 story; Emerson]

Even for those works surviving in more than one version, a documentary rather than eclectic approach is preferable since one interest in juvenilia and youthful writing must reside in the possible collaboration represented by any given version. Ruskinʼs early texts probably rarely represent the collaborative play at the pitch of the Brontesʼ plays and sagas. The family letters amply show that he shared his writing with his parents, however, and any given version might reflect a spectrum of collaboration. Admittedly, orthographic evidence of some form of joint writing is scarce (e.g., Ruskin and Mary Richardsonʼs 1830 diary; Ruskin and his fatherʼs commonplace book); and even orthographic examples of the boyʼs writing and a parentʼs editing are not common (e.g., ??). But the letters show repeatedly that Ruskin wrote primarily for his parentsʼ ears, and that he heard their voices, particularly his fatherʼs, as he drafted and revised his works.
